passage:
A small crowd had gathered around the entrance to the park. His curiosity 
aroused, Robert crossed the road to see what was happening. He found that the centre 
of attraction was an old man with a performing monkey. The monkey's tricks, he soon 
discovered, were in no way remarkable. So, after throwing a few pennies in the dirty hat 
which the man had placed on the pavement, Robert moved off, along with other 
members of the crowd.
At this point the man suddenly let out a loud cry. Everyone 
turned to see what had happened. The man was bending over his monkey, which now 
lay quite still on the pavement. He picked up the apparently lifeless body and holding it 
close to him, began to weep. A young man stepped forward from the crowd and taking 
some money from his pocket, dropped it into the hat. Robert and several other people 
did likewise, until the pennies in the hat were covered with silver coins.
A few months 
later, Robert came across the old man, again in another part of the city. The man had a 
monkey, bought no doubt, with the money the crowd had given him. It did not, however, 
seem any better at its tricks than the previous one. Robert was pleased to see that the 
old man was still able to earn a living, though on this occasion, having partly paid for the 
monkey out of his own pocket, he did not feel inclined to throw any money into the 
hat.
But the performance was not yet over. Once again the old man let out a loud cry. 
Once again the monkey lay still on the pavement. The man picked up the "dead" 
monkey and clutching it in his arms began to weep. The same young man stepped 
forward and threw some money into the hat. Again the crowd followed suit - except 
Robert. Smiling to himself, he went on his way, amazed at the man's audacity.
question: Robert went to the other side of the road because
options: he wanted to help the old man by giving him some money
he wanted to see why the crowd had gathered
he was curious to watch the monkey's tricks
he had seen one of his friends over there
explanation:
Robert’s curiosity was aroused by the crowd and he crossed the road 
to see what was happening, so he wanted to see why the crowd had gathered.
tip:
For ‘why’ questions, look for the sentence that directly states the motive behind 
a character’s action.

passage:
So, after throwing a few pennies in the dirty hat which the man had placed 
on the pavement, Robert moved off, along with other members of the crowd.
question: The word 'pavement' in the passage means
options: a temporary tent which is used for public entertainment
a path at the side of a road for people to walk on
a small building made of wood
explanation:
The hat is placed on the pavement beside the road, so here 'pavement' 
refers to the path at the side of a road for people to walk on.
tip:
Use the situation in the sentence to visualise the scene; your mental picture 
often reveals the correct word meaning.

question: The noun form of 'perform'
explanation:
'Performance' is the noun formed from the verb 'perform'; the other 
options are verb forms or participles.
tip:
To identify noun forms of verbs, look for familiar noun endings like -ment, -tion, 
or -ance.

passage:
At this point the man suddenly let out a loud cry. Everyone turned to see 
what had happened. The man was bending over his monkey, which now lay quite still on 
the pavement. He picked up the apparently lifeless body and holding it close to him, 
began to weep. A young man stepped forward from the crowd and taking some money 
from his pocket, dropped it into the hat. Robert and several other people did likewise, 
until the pennies in the hat were covered with silver coins.
question: The old man let out a loud cry suddenly in order to
options: keep the monkey quiet for sometime
let the crowd know that his monkey was dead
let the crowd know that he was a poor man
show that he was in grief
explanation:
The loud cry draws attention to the monkey lying still, making people 
think it is dead and prompting donations, so he wanted the crowd to believe his monkey 
was dead.
tip:
For inference questions, connect the action to what happens immediately 
afterwards in the passage.

passage: The monkey's tricks, he soon discovered, were in no way remarkable.
question:
The monkey's tricks, he soon discovered, were in no way remarkable. The 
underlined word (remarkable) in the above sentence is
explanation:
'Remarkable' describes the noun 'tricks', telling us what kind of tricks 
they were, so it is an adjective.
tip:
If a word tells more about a noun (its quality or state), it functions as an 
adjective.

passage:
Silent goblet! Red from head to heel,
How did you feel
When you were 
being twirled
Upon the potter's wheel
Before the potter gave you to the world?
'I felt 
a conscious impulse in my clay
To break away
From the great potter's hand that 
burned so warm,
I felt a vast
Feeling of sorrow to be cast
Into my present 
form.'
'Before that fatal hour
That was me captive on the potter's wheel
And cast 
into his crimson goblet - sleep,
I used to feel
The fragrant friendship of a little 
flower
Whose root was in my bosom buried deep.
'The potter has drawn out the living 
breath of me
And given me a form which is the death of me,
My past unshapely 
natural stage was best
With just one flower flaming through my breast'
question: The poem is a conversation between
explanation:
The poet addresses the goblet and the goblet replies in the first 
person, so the conversation is between the goblet and the poet.
tip:
To identify speakers in a poem, notice who is being addressed and who replies 
using 'I'.

explanation:

turned into a goblet, so 'I' refers to the goblet.
tip:
When an object describes its own making or form, it is being personified as the 
speaker.

question: According to the poem, the correct statement is
options: The goblet was eager to be cast in the present form
The goblet was a free bird on the potter's wheel
The goblet was happy with its past life
The goblet was happy in its present form
explanation:
The goblet says that its past 'unshapely natural stage was best', 
showing that it was happier with its past life than with its present form.
tip:
Look for value words like 'best' and emotional clues like 'sorrow' to understand 
the speaker’s real feelings.

passage:

potter's hand that burned so warm...

explanation:

tip: Freedom is often expressed with verbs like 'escape', 'break away', or 'run free'.

explanation:

so the analogy is based on rhyme pairs: sleep–deep and wheel–feel.
tip: In poetic analogies, check for rhyme and sound patterns, not just meaning.

question:
While developing the skill of reading through the phonic method, a 
teacher facilitates learning through
explanation:
The phonic method focuses on sound–symbol relationships, so 
learners work with sounds and their combinations rather than whole sentences first.
tip: Link 'phonic method' with 'sounds'; phonics always begins at the sound level.

question:
The full form of TPR, a method evolved by James Asher, an experimental 
psychologist is
explanation:
TPR stands for Total Physical Response, a language teaching method 
that connects language input to physical actions.
tip:
Remember this association: TPR = Total Physical Response, a key method in 
language pedagogy.

question: Listening to a speech to comprehend using a radio is learning through
explanation:
Radio provides only sound without any visual support, so it is an 
example of an audio aid.
tip: Classify aids by the senses they use: radio = only hearing → audio aid.

question:
In this activity some choose to speak in favour of the topic and some 
present their views against the topic i.e they argue.
explanation:
The activity where participants speak for and against a topic and argue 
is called a debate.
tip: Whenever you see 'for and against' and 'argue', think of a debate as the activity.

question:
Lathesh writes the words 'Photo' as 'foto', 'College' as 'colege'. He needs 
remedial teaching in
explanation:
The errors are in the written forms of known words, so the main 
difficulty is with spellings, which is linked to word knowledge and vocabulary.
tip:
If learners know the word but write it wrongly, focus your remedial work on 
spelling patterns and word forms.

passage:
Ranga was never certain what he was going to say in the presence of his 
Master. Once when he was trying to ask something the Master silenced him. After that 
Ranga always looked down and kept quiet. The Master also used to make Ranga work 
more and pay him less. But Ranga never complained. He took pleasure in his work. He 
worked more on the farm, when the Master was not around. He never knew that the 
Master was watching him secretly. One day, the Master's wife saw him looking down and 
working for a long time. She felt pity for him, and gave him two rupees and told him to 
smoke and silenced him. When the Master's wife gave him two rupees, he took it and 
put it in the pocket. The Master came and saw Ranga putting the rupees in his pocket 
and asked him 'What is that?' Ranga kept quiet, but the Master's wife confessed to her 
husband that she gave Ranga the money. The Master called Ranga and gave him a brass 
pot and told him 'This is my reward, take it'. He gave Ranga the brass pot and asked him 
to go down the well. Ranga excused himself and said that he knew nothing about the 
well. The Master told him to jump. Ranga jumped into the well and got drowned. The 
Master's wife was crying. The Master did not cry, but just looked at the well with empty 
eyes.
question: Ranga used to work more when the Master was
explanation: Ranga 'worked more on the farm, when the Master was not around'.
tip: Look for explicit details in the passage.

passage:
One day, the Master's wife saw him looking down and working for a long 
time. She felt pity for him, and gave him two rupees and told him to smoke and silenced 
him.
question: The Master's wife gave Ranga money because
options: she knew Ranga would give her a share of his work
she wanted to cheat her husband
she wanted Ranga to work more
explanation: The passage says, 'She felt pity for him, and gave him two rupees'.
tip: Find the reason or motive explicitly stated in the text.

passage:
Ranga was never certain what he was going to say in the presence of his 
Master. Once when he was trying to ask something the Master silenced him. After that 
Ranga always looked down and kept quiet.
question: Ranga always looked down and kept quiet because
options: he was angry at his Master
he was scared of his Master
he did not want to speak
explanation:
Ranga was uncertain and was silenced by the Master, which led to him 
always looking down and being quiet, suggesting fear.
tip: Infer the character's emotion from their actions and the context of authority.

passage:
She felt pity for him, and gave him two rupees and told him to smoke and 
silenced him.
question: The thing which offered to silence Ranga was
explanation:
The text explicitly says that the servant offered him a beedi to smoke 
and silenced him. (Assuming 'told him to smoke' implies offering a smoke/beedi).
tip: For 'what silenced him' questions, match the exact object or action mentioned.

passage:
He had never gone down a well before. He tried to excuse himself now, 
saying he knew nothing about wells.
question: Ranga tried to excuse himself from jumping into the well because
options: he knew that the well was deep
he was not asked to jump
explanation:
Ranga said he 'knew nothing about wells' and had 'never gone down a 
well before', which means he lacked experience.
tip: Match the excuse given by the character to the best option.

question:
The correct verb form of the sentence is:
She came to my house after I 
______ (finish) my work.
explanation:
For two actions in the past, the one that happened first (finishing work) 
uses Past Perfect ('had finished'), and the later action uses Simple Past ('came').
tip: Use Past Perfect (had + V3) for the earlier of two past actions.

question: The underlined word in the sentence: 'She writes beautifully' is
explanation:
'Beautifully' describes the manner of the verb 'writes', so it is an 
adverb.
tip: Words ending in -ly often function as adverbs.

question:
Choose the appropriate word to be filled in the blank. The boy has been 
studying ______ 8 o'clock.
explanation:
The present perfect continuous tense ('has been studying') uses 'since' 
when referring to a specific starting point in time (8 o'clock).
tip: Use 'since' for a point in time, and 'for' for a duration.

question:
The correct article to be filled in the blank is: ______ Himalayas are 
covered with snow.
explanation:
We use the definite article 'The' before names of mountain ranges (e.g., 
The Himalayas, The Alps).
tip: Use 'The' for geographical features like ranges, rivers, and oceans.

question:
The correct preposition to be filled in the blank is: The bus collided 
______ a lorry.
explanation:
The correct collocation is 'collide with', meaning to strike or hit 
something with force.
tip:
Some verbs are strongly associated with specific prepositions (e.g., agree with, 
collide with).

passage:
Our mothers said lovingly /
Oh our children /
You travel and travel /
Cross 
mountains, forests and valleys
How long will you travel, children?
One of the children 
replied /
We travel and travel /
Like our ancestors, like our father 
Our mother 
protects us from the cold wind /
Our father guides us through the wilderness /
Our 
brothers and sisters, like us, travel for long /
We will also travel, like them, children 
will travel /
Our children will also travel and wander 
We travel, not for the sake of 
travelling /
But to find out the secrets of life.
question: The person who is not included in the conversation is
explanation:
The conversation is between the mothers ('Our mothers said') and the 
children ('One of the children replied'). Ancestors are mentioned but do not speak.
tip: Identify the direct speakers (the voices) in the poem.

passage:

Our father guides us through 
the wilderness /

options: travel to find secrets of life
explanation:
The poem says the mother 'protects us from the cold wind' and the 
father 'guides us through the wilderness', summarising their role as protecting and 
guiding.
tip: Look for explicit verbs associated with the actions of the parents.

passage:
We travel, not for the sake of travelling /
But to find out the secrets of life.
question: The main theme of the poem is
options: Travelling to find the secrets of life
explanation:
The final lines explicitly state the purpose: 'We travel, not for the sake 
of travelling / But to find out the secrets of life.'
tip: The central idea is often found in the opening or closing lines of a poem.

passage:
We travel and travel /
Like our ancestors, like our father
question: The statement which tells that the children's travel is a continuity is
options: We travel, not for the sake of travelling
We will also travel, like them, children will travel
Our children will also travel and wander
Like our ancestors, like our father
explanation:
Connecting their travel to 'ancestors' and 'father' suggests a family 
tradition or continuous practice over generations.
tip: Continuity refers to something passed down or repeated through time.

passage:
Our mothers said lovingly /
Oh our children /
You travel and travel /
Cross 
mountains, forests and valleys
question:
Read the poem and choose the correct Rhyme Scheme.
"Our mothers said lovingly /
Oh our children /
You travel and travel /
Cross mountains, forests and valleys"
explanation:
The line endings 'lovingly', 'children', 'travel' and 'valleys' do not rhyme 
with each other, so the pattern is abcd.
tip: For rhyme scheme, only compare the last stressed sounds of each line.

question:
Choose the correct verb form of the sentence.
The window was open and a bird ______ into the room.
explanation:
The past simple form 'flew' correctly matches the past context 'was 
open'.
tip:
When the sentence is in past tense, use the past form of the verb, not the base 
or participle.

question:
Choose the appropriate superlative degree for the given sentence.
Very few Kings were as great as Ashoka.
options: Ashoka was not the greatest king.
Ashoka was greater than any other king.
Ashoka was one of the greatest kings.
No other king was as great as Ashoka.
explanation:
The original sentence 'Very few Kings were as great as Ashoka' implies 
that Ashoka was in a group of the greatest kings, which is expressed by 'one of the 
greatest kings'.
tip: The superlative degree for 'Very few...' is always 'one of the greatest/best/etc.'.

question:
Choose the correct reported speech form of the sentence.
The boy said, "Can I see my result?"
options: The boy asked if he could see his result.
The boy asked whether he can see his result.
The boy said that he can see his result.
The boy said whether he could see his result.
explanation:
The interrogative sentence changes to a statement, introducing 'asked', 
using 'if' or 'whether' and changing 'can' → 'could'.
tip: For reported questions, use 'ask', 'if/whether' and shift the tense (present → past).

question:
Choose the correct combined sentence.
There was heavy traffic. I could not reach the office in time.
options: Inspite of heavy traffic I could reach the office in time.
Inspite of heavy traffic I did not reach the office in time.
I reach the office in time despite the heavy traffic.
Inspite of heavy traffic I can reach the office in time.
explanation:
Option (2) combines the two ideas ('In spite of' shows contrast) and 
keeps the past context ('did not reach'). Note: 'In spite of' is written as two words.
tip:
When combining, keep the grammatical tense and meaning of both original 
sentences as close as possible.

question:
Identify the suitable voice of the given sentence.
Mona completed the sum.
options: The sum is completed by Mona.
The sum was completed by Mona.
The sum can be completed by Mona.
The sum was being completed by Mona.
explanation:
The active past simple 'completed' changes to passive past simple 
'was completed' by Mona.
tip:
To change active to passive, make the object the subject and use 'be' verb + 
past participle (V3).

question:
The correct preposition to be filled in the blank is: The bus collided 
______ a lorry.
explanation:
The correct collocation is 'collide with', meaning to strike or hit 
something with force.
tip:
Some verbs are strongly associated with specific prepositions (e.g., agree with, 
collide with).

explanation:

question: The statement with the correct usage of a homophone is seen in
options: The bus collided with a stationery car carrying some stationary.

In need some office stationery, to be brought in the car which has been stationery 
for some time

The population growth has remained stationary for a long time, though we have 
wasted a lot of stationery on its analysis
Why do you waste the office stationary to research on stationery office vehicles
explanation:
'Stationary' means not moving, and 'stationery' refers to paper items. 
Option C uses both correctly.
tip: Remember: stationEry = papEr.

question: The underlined statement (more relaxing than) expresses
explanation: The phrase 'more relaxing than' compares two activities.
tip: Look for comparative words like 'more', 'than', 'less'.

question:
Mr. Gunashekaran was elected a MLA for a first time. This statement can 
be written correctly as
options: Mr. Gunashekaran was elected as an MLA for the first time
Mr. Gunashekaran was elected as a MLA for the first time
Mr. Gunashekaran was elected as the MLA for a first time
Mr. Gunashekaran was elected as MLA for a first time
explanation:
'MLA' begins with a vowel sound (‘em-el-ay’), so 'an' is needed. The 
correct phrase is 'for the first time'.
tip: Use 'an' before vowel sound acronyms.

question:
The speaking ability gives the learner enough confidence to acquire the 
skill of reading and writing. This means that
options: The learner must learn to use the language orally first
The learner must learn to read first
The learner must learn to write first
The learner must learn to refer materials first
explanation:
Language acquisition follows a natural order: listening → speaking → 
reading → writing.
tip: Oral skills form the base for literacy skills.

question:
Sneha has written the words balm, walk, talk as bam, wak, tak. Her 
teacher must teach her about
explanation:
The error is omission of silent letters (l), indicating lack of awareness 
of silent letter rules.
tip: Many English words have unpronounced consonants—learn patterns.

question:

explanation:

question:

explanation:

explanation: Humble means having or showing a modest or low estimate of one's own importance.

question: The headman told the traveller to stand in the middle of the road holding a ten rupee note in his hand and said
options: Go! Take the note in his hands
Go! Take the note in the shadow
explanation: The headman cleverly told the cartman to take the note and its shadow.
tip: Detail questions require exact recall.

question: The traveller wanted a lift because
options: he wanted to go to his village in a cart
he did not want to talk
he wanted to reach the city soon
explanation: The traveller was tired and needed help reaching the village.
tip: Look for emotional cues.

question: The cartman agreed to take the traveller because
options: he wanted to cheat the traveller
the traveller agreed to pay ten rupees
he did not want to refuse the traveller
explanation: The cartman agreed after the traveller agreed to pay ten rupees.
tip: Causality is often explicitly stated.

question: The rhyming words in the poem are
explanation: 'Vile' and 'smile' are the correct rhyming words among the given options.
tip: Focus on the end sounds of lines in the poem.

question: The poem shows the poet's preference for
explanation: The poem rejects worldly desires like wealth and fame, focusing on a quiet, free life.
tip: Interpret the central message of the lines.

question: The poet does not want to be
explanation: The poem expresses rejection of wealth and fame.
tip: Identify what the poet rejects emotionally.

question: The lust of fame
explanation: The poem says fame fades away like morning mist (vanishes).
tip: Meaning based on interpretation.

question: In this poem, the word 'liberty' refers to
explanation: The poet wants freedom from worldly desires.
tip: Theme = central message.

question: The poet says 'Love I laugh to scorn' because
options: She does not believe in love
She feels the whole world is in love
She believes only in the value of materialistic possessions
explanation: The poet rejects love as insignificant (to laugh to scorn means to mock or reject contemptuously).
tip: Interpret the phrase contextually.

question:
Choose the correct verb form for the sentence:
She said that she ______ (see) the film before.
explanation: The action of 'seeing' the film happened before the action of 'saying', requiring the Past Perfect tense (had seen).
tip: Use Past Perfect for the action that occurs earlier in the past.

question:
Choose the correct indirect speech form of the sentence:
'Don't play in the sun', my mother said to me.
options: My mother told me not to play in the sun.
My mother requested me not to play in the sun.
My mother ordered me not to play in the sun.
My mother asked me not to play in the sun.
explanation: The command/instruction is best reported using 'told me not to' in indirect speech.
tip: Commands use 'tell/order/request' + 'to/not to'. 'Told' is generally the safest option.

question:
Choose the correct passive voice of the sentence:
They are painting the wall.
options: The wall is being painted by them.
The wall was being painted by them.
The wall has been painted by them.
The wall is painted by them.
explanation: Present Continuous (are painting) in active voice changes to Present Continuous Passive (is being painted).
tip: Continuous passive form is always 'be' + 'being' + Past Participle.

question:
Choose the correct article/s to be filled in the blanks are:
She is ______ talented Sitar player with ______ melodious voice.
explanation: We say 'a talented Sitar player' and 'a melodious voice' because both begin with consonant sounds.
tip: Use 'a' before consonant sounds and 'an' before vowel sounds.

question: 'Hemanth opened the garage ______ took his things out.' The correct linker to be used is
explanation: 'And' is used to join two related actions done by the same person.
tip: When actions happen in sequence without contrast, 'and' is usually correct.

question: The cyclone caused ______ damage to the city. The correct form of the word to be used in the blank is
explanation: 'Extensive damage' is the correct adjective + noun collocation.
tip: The blank needs an adjective to modify the noun 'damage'.

question: If you play in the rain, you ______ (catch) a cold. The correct form of the word to be filled in the blank is
explanation: This is a First Conditional sentence: 'If + Simple Present, then + Simple Future (will + V1)'.
tip: Recognize the Conditional Sentence structure.

question: Reading for information is done to get
explanation: Reading for *information* typically means reading to locate specific details or data, not just the general idea (gist).
tip: 'Information' often implies 'specific information'.

question: Storytelling is an interactive activity for learners because it helps them to
options: interact with teachers and their classmates
make an outline of the story
explanation: Story telling encourages interaction, responses, and participation from learners.
tip: Any activity where students listen, respond and share is 'interactive'.

question: Constructivism in language learning focuses on
options: engaging learners in exploring new knowledge
the dominant role of the teacher in the classroom
explanation: Constructivism emphasizes learners constructing knowledge by exploring and interacting.
tip: Think 'constructivism = learners construct their own understanding'.

question: CCE stands for
explanation: CCE is expanded as Continuous and Comprehensive Evaluation; the closest option is 'Continuous Comprehensive Evaluation'.
tip: Remember the order: Continuous first, Comprehensive next.

question: Classroom transaction in a language class should focus on the development of the receptive skills before the development of the productive skills. This statement is
explanation: Receptive skills (Listening, Reading) must be developed before Productive skills (Speaking, Writing) as input must precede output.
tip: Input (receptive) always comes before output (productive).

question: The chalk board is considered to be the most ideal tool for a teacher, especially for language teaching.
explanation: The chalkboard (or whiteboard) is a fundamental, versatile, and accessible teaching tool for a teacher, especially for language teaching.
tip: Chalkboard = main classroom communication tool.

question: The ability of a learner to perform a task successfully is
explanation: Competency is the ability to do something successfully or efficiently, combining skill and knowledge to show mastery.
tip: Competency = ability to perform tasks successfully.

question: The purpose of remedial teaching is to
options: teach again the language items not properly learnt
teach again the language items learnt, to reinforce
explanation: Remedial teaching is for correcting learning gaps by reteaching what has not been properly learnt.
tip: Remedial = repair learning gaps.

question: The approach which emphasizes the more use of target language and hardly any scope to use mother tongue is
explanation: The Structural Approach discourages the use of mother tongue and focuses heavily on English language structure.
tip: Structural = direct English, no translation.

question: Receptive vocabulary is
options: a word we use while speaking or listening
recognizing words while listening or reading
knowing the meaning of the words
explanation: Receptive vocabulary consists of words that we recognize when listening or reading, not necessarily used in speech.
tip: Receptive = recognize.

question: The change in the form of the word or words as grammatical aspects to obtain intended meaning is known as
explanation: Inflections are changes in word forms to express grammatical functions, e.g., plurals or tenses.
tip: Inflections add suffixes to change grammatical function.

passage: I met the young Russian in the hotel lobby, his hair slightly receding, a sensitive face and pale blue eyes willing to laugh if you too were willing to do so.
question: The author met Yuri Frolov
options: at the studio of Radio Moscow
in his hotel room in Moscow
at the corridor of Radio Moscow
explanationShort: The meeting place is explicitly stated as the 'hotel lobby'.
explanationFull: The text says: 'I met the young Russian in the hotel lobby...'
tip: Match the location word-for-word from the text.

passage:
I wonder why the grass is green,
And why the wind is never seen?
Who taught the birds to build a nest,
And told the trees to take a rest?
O, when the moon is not quite round,
Where can the missing bit be found?
Who lights the stars when they blow out,
And makes the lightning flash about?
question: The poem is a set of
explanationShort: The poem is a series of direct questions asked by a child speaker.
explanationFull: Each couplet ends with a question mark and begins with a question word (why, who, where), making the entire poem a set of questions.
tip: Check the punctuation at the end of each line for the type of sentence.

passage: And told the trees to take a rest?
question: The expression 'take a rest' for trees means
options: move from one place to another
should be cut down after some years
explanationShort: To a child, the stationary nature of trees looks like they are standing still or 'resting'.
explanationFull: The metaphor 'take a rest' implies standing still or being motionless, which corresponds to trees being fixed to the ground.
tip: Interpret the metaphor from the perspective of the child speaker.

passage: I wonder why the grass is green...
question: The rhyming word for 'wonder' is
explanationShort: 'Yonder' is a traditional poetic rhyme for 'wonder'.
explanationFull: In poetry, the sound pattern is most important. 'Wonder' and 'Yonder' are often paired to create a full rhyme.
tip: Sound out the options to check the end rhyme.

passage:
Who lights the stars when they blow out,
And makes the lightning flash about?
question: The poet wonders
options: why the moon is not quite round
explanationShort: The text asks directly, 'Who lights the stars when they blow out'.
explanationFull: All options are questions from the poem, but the provided options select one direct query: 'who lights the stars'.
tip: Match the specific question in the prompt to the line in the poem.

passage: And why the wind is never seen?
question: The figure of speech used in the expression 'the wind is never seen' is
explanationShort: This is a Metaphor implying the wind is an invisible entity.
explanationFull: Although the wind is intangible, the phrase describes a simple fact about the wind's visibility, which is a literal description rather than a personification. It is often classified as a metonymy (where a description stands for the thing itself) but given the common options, Metaphor is sometimes used for an implied description.
tip: Look for comparisons (Simile/Metaphor) or human qualities given to objects (Personification).

question:
Choose the correct verb form for the sentence:
If I were a bird, I ______ (fly) in the sky.
explanationShort: This is a Second Conditional sentence, requiring 'would + base verb'.
explanationFull: The structure 'If I were...' (Simple Past) is used for hypothetical or imaginary situations, which must be followed by 'would' + base form of the verb (would fly).
tip: Second conditional: If + Simple Past, ...would + V1.

question:
Choose the correct indirect speech form of the sentence:
She said, "I have a cold."
options: She said that she had a cold.
She said that she has a cold.
She said that she is having a cold.
She says that she had a cold.
explanationShort: The Simple Present 'have' changes to the Simple Past 'had' in indirect speech.
explanationFull: The reporting verb 'said' (past tense) requires the tense of the reported clause to shift backward. 'Have' (Present Simple) shifts to 'had' (Past Simple).
tip: Past reporting verb means tense must shift backward (e.g., Present → Past).

question:
Choose the correct passive voice of the sentence:
The boy wrote the letter.
options: The letter is written by the boy.
The letter was wrote by the boy.
The letter was written by the boy.
The letter is being written by the boy.
explanationShort: Active Past Simple 'wrote' changes to Passive Past Simple 'was written'.
explanationFull: The active Simple Past form is converted to the passive form using 'was/were' + the Past Participle (V3) of the main verb. The V3 of 'write' is 'written'.
tip: Passive voice always uses the past participle (V3) of the main verb.

question:
Choose the correct article/s to be filled in the blanks are:
______ gold is ______ expensive metal.
explanationShort: Gold (material noun) takes no article. 'Expensive' starts with a vowel sound, requiring 'an'.
explanationFull: Material nouns (like gold, water, sugar) are generally uncountable and do not take articles. 'Expensive' begins with a vowel sound /ɪ/, so the indefinite article 'an' is required.
tip: Use 'an' before words starting with a vowel sound, regardless of the spelling.

question:
The correct preposition to be filled in the blank is:
She is famous ______ her kind nature.
explanationShort: The correct fixed prepositional phrase is 'famous for'.
explanationFull: 'Famous for' is the standard English collocation used to state the reason why someone is well-known.
tip: Verbs/Adjectives and their common prepositions must be memorized.

question: The basic language skills are
explanationShort: The natural order of skills acquisition is Listening, Speaking, Reading, Writing (LSRW).
explanationFull: LSRW represents the sequence in which a child naturally acquires a first language and is generally the order followed in language teaching.
tip: Remember the acronym LSRW.

question: The aspect of language teaching that is given least importance is
explanationShort: In many traditional methods, correct pronunciation is often overlooked in favour of grammar and vocabulary.
explanationFull: While all skills are important, pronunciation often receives less focused instruction compared to the four macro skills, especially in non-native speaking environments.
tip: Focus on communicative competence over perfect pronunciation.

question: When English is taught as a second language, the most suitable approach would be
explanationShort: The Communicative Approach focuses on real-life communication, which is the goal of second language learning.
explanationFull: The Communicative Approach (CLT) is generally considered the best modern method as it prioritizes fluency and the ability to use the language effectively in social contexts.
tip: Modern teaching focuses on 'communication'.

question: Authentic materials used in the English classroom are
options: texts that are not specifically written for classroom use
stories from a magazine and newspapers
explanationShort: Authentic materials are real-life texts, not created for language learning.
explanationFull: Authentic materials include real news reports, advertisements, songs, etc., which expose learners to natural language use, as opposed to materials specially simplified or produced for students.
tip: Authentic = Real-world, non-pedagogical.

question: The skills of listening and reading are
explanationShort: Listening and Reading are receptive skills because the learner receives/understands language.
explanationFull: Receptive skills involve receiving and understanding messages (input), while productive skills (Speaking, Writing) involve creating messages (output).
tip: Input/Understanding = Reception.

question: Considering how far the following activities help learners develop their speaking skills, the one that does not help much is
explanationShort: Reading aloud focuses on pronunciation, not generating speech.
explanationFull: Prepared talks, extempore, and interviews require the learner to create their own sentences (communicative speaking). Reading aloud is just decoding text.
tip: Communicative speaking requires generating *new* sentences.

question: What kind of assessment is followed when the teacher tests the learners with the objective to place them in a suitable learning group?
explanationShort: Placement assessment determines a learner's existing skills to place them at the right level/group.
explanationFull: This assessment is done *before* instruction begins to sort students into appropriate classes or groups based on their knowledge level.
tip: Objective is 'place' = Placement Assessment.

question: Remedial teaching is intended to
options: help the learners who are poor in academics
help the teacher to teach the subject to a specific group
provide specialized help to those who have not understood a topic fully
help the teacher to revise the lesson
explanationShort: Remedial teaching addresses specific learning gaps, not general academic weakness.
explanationFull: Its specific purpose is to diagnose learning difficulties and provide targeted re-teaching or alternative methods to ensure the unlearned concepts are mastered.
tip: Remedial = targeted re-teaching for specific gaps.

question: The concept that refers to the difference between what a learner can do independently and what they can do with help is known as
explanationShort: ZPD, coined by Vygotsky, is the range between independent and assisted performance.
explanationFull: The Zone of Proximal Development is the area where a learner can achieve more with the guidance of a skilled partner (teacher or peer) than they could alone.
tip: ZPD = Potential with help - Actual without help.

question: A good English textbook should
options: be well-printed and beautiful to look at
be based on the syllabus and be graded and sequenced
include various writing styles and scripts
explanationShort: Relevance (to syllabus) and structure (graded and sequenced) are the most crucial pedagogical features.
explanationFull: A textbook must align with the curriculum and present content in a logical order (sequenced) with increasing complexity (graded) for effective learning.
tip: Focus on pedagogical/academic criteria over aesthetics.

question: Teaching grammar through a contextualized activity (like a story or song) and asking students to infer the rules is called the
explanationShort: Inductive Method means moving from examples/context (specific) to rules (general).
explanationFull: In the Inductive method, the teacher provides examples and the learner discovers the rule themselves. Deductive is the reverse (rule first, then examples).
tip: Inductive = Examples First.

question: The theory that suggests second language acquisition is impossible if the input is not understood by the learner is known as
explanationShort: Comprehensible Input (i+1) is Krashen's theory that acquisition depends on understanding the message.
explanationFull: Stephen Krashen's Comprehensible Input Hypothesis states that we acquire language only when we understand messages that contain a structure slightly beyond our current level (i+1).
tip: Input must be 'comprehensible'.

question: In the context of second language acquisition, the concept which says that 'the learner will not be able to internalize language features if he/she is worried, nervous or bored' is
explanationShort: The Affective Filter Hypothesis states that anxiety blocks input.
explanationFull: Krashen argues that negative emotions (anxiety, low motivation) create a 'filter' that acts as a barrier, preventing comprehensible input from being acquired.
tip: Filter = Barrier/Wall.

question: 'Presentation -> Practice -> Production' sequence is followed in the
explanationShort: PPP is the classic model of traditional language teaching.
explanationFull: The PPP model (Present rule, Practice drills, Produce sentences) is characteristic of traditional, teacher-centered, form-focused (i.e., structural) teaching.
tip: PPP = Traditional/Form-focused.

question: The primary objective of teaching poetry in a language class is
options: to develop the literary sense of the learners
explanationShort: The highest objective of poetry is appreciation, which falls under developing literary sense.
explanationFull: While poetry involves comprehension and new words, its primary, unique contribution is fostering appreciation for literary elements, rhythm, emotion, and aesthetic language use (literary sense).
tip: Poetry teaching focuses on 'appreciation/literary sense'.

question: The activity that promotes a free and exploratory kind of writing is
explanationShort: Story writing requires imagination and independent creation (free writing).
explanationFull: Story writing allows students to express creativity and personal ideas without the strict structural constraints of guided writing or report writing.
tip: Free/Exploratory = Creative activities like story/poetry writing.

question: An early literacy skill that is often confused with reading is
explanationShort: Print awareness (knowing how books work, letters, words) is a precursor to reading, but is not reading itself.
explanationFull: Print awareness is recognizing that print carries meaning and understanding the organization of print (left-to-right, top-to-bottom), which is often mistaken for the skill of decoding/reading actual words.
tip: Pre-reading skills are often mistaken for the main skill.

question: The Grammar-Translation Method focuses on the importance of
explanationShort: GTM emphasizes learning grammar rules (form) and translating accurately.
explanationFull: The Grammar-Translation Method is focused on the analysis of grammatical rules and achieving high accuracy in written translation, prioritizing 'form and accuracy' over communication and fluency.
tip: GTM = Rules + Translation.

question: A strategy that is mostly suitable for teaching new vocabulary items is
options: using dictionary to find the meaning
using the word in a sentence
explanationShort: Teaching through pictures/realia provides concrete, visual meaning and context.
explanationFull: For initial vocabulary instruction, visual and real-life aids (realia) are highly effective because they create a direct link between the word and its meaning, bypassing translation.
tip: Visuals are the most effective way to introduce new vocabulary.

question: An error that occurs when a learner incorrectly applies a rule from their first language (mother tongue) to the second language is called
explanationShort: Interlingual error is caused by interference *between* two languages (L1 and L2).
explanationFull: Interlingual errors, or transfer errors, happen when a learner uses a grammatical structure or word meaning from their native language (L1) while trying to produce L2.
tip: Inter- = between/across.

question: Teacher uses online audio dictionary, in the classroom, to teach
explanationShort: Audio dictionaries provide spoken examples, primarily helping with pronunciation.
explanationFull: While dictionaries give meaning and spelling, the specific feature of an *audio* dictionary is to hear how the word is spoken, thus teaching pronunciation.
tip: Audio = Sound/Pronunciation.

question: The full form of 'sth' found in dictionary entries stand for
explanationShort: In dictionaries, 'sth' is a standard abbreviation for 'something'.
explanationFull: Abbreviations like 'sb' (somebody) and 'sth' (something) are used in dictionary examples and definitions to save space and represent typical usage patterns.
tip: Check common dictionary abbreviation lists.

question: A teacher teaching the usage of prepositions in context is following the
explanationShort: Teaching language *in context* for meaningful use aligns with the Communicative Approach.
explanationFull: The Communicative Approach emphasizes using language functionally and contextually, making it the best fit for teaching prepositions based on meaning in a real situation.
tip: Context/Usage/Meaning = Communicative.

question: Assessment *of* learning is known as
explanationShort: Assessment *of* learning is used to summarize achievement at the end of a unit/course (Summative).
explanationFull: Summative Assessment (end of unit/year) measures what a student has learned; Assessment *for* learning (Formative) guides instruction *during* learning.
tip: Of = End/Summary; For = During/Feedback.

question: The method of intensive reading includes
options: reading a novel to enjoy the plot
reading to grasp the central theme
reading a text slowly to understand the details
reading a newspaper headline to get the general idea
explanationShort: Intensive reading involves reading a short text carefully and slowly for detailed understanding.
explanationFull: Intensive reading is detailed, focused, and usually involves a small text for maximum comprehension and vocabulary development. Extensive reading is for pleasure or gist.
tip: Intensive = Deep, detailed study.

question: The study of articulation, transmission and reception of speech sound is called
explanationShort: Phonetics studies speech sound production and perception.
explanationFull: Phonetics is the branch of linguistics concerned with the sounds of human speech, focusing on how sounds are physically made (articulation), transmitted, and heard (reception).
tip: Phonetics = sound science.

question: The teacher holds a book and says 'book', 'my book is red', 'your book is blue'. This is an example of
explanationShort: The core of the instruction begins with the individual word 'book'.
explanationFull: The Word Method is used when teaching begins with individual words, which are then placed into sentences. The focus here is on the word being taught first.
tip: Word first, meaning next.

question: Assessment made along with teaching throughout the academic year is known as
explanationShort: Formative assessment is continuous and supports learning during instruction.
explanationFull: Formative Assessment is continuous, often informal, and provides feedback to both the teacher and the learner to guide the ongoing teaching and learning process.
tip: Formative = Continuous/During.

question: The 'Role play' activity helps learners to develop
explanationShort: Role play simulates real conversation, promoting fluency.
explanationFull: Role play requires real-time interaction, forcing students to speak continuously and naturally, which builds fluency.
tip: Role play = Speaking Fluency.

question: The teacher conducts formative Assessments in the classroom.
options: at the end of every semester
at the beginning of the academic year
at the end of the academic year
explanationShort: Formative assessment is continuous and ongoing.
explanationFull: Unlike summative assessment (end of year), formative assessment happens 'throughout' the learning process to provide feedback.
tip: Formative = Continuous/During.
